utterances: You know, when we got on the plane, a British citizen who was there for a six- week vacation, cut his vacation short by five weeks.
And he was desperate to get on this trip.
And when he had got on the plane and he sat down, he had a heart attack and he died.
And so we had to delay the flight.
Laura, this was on the flight that you were on?
This was on the flight that I was on.
We had to wait for him to be carted off the plane.
I didn't see him carted off the plane.
I didn't see him die.
But the passengers on the airline were abuzz.
Laura, you deal with civil liberties issues every day.
Will your experience there in some way inform your work here?
Has it changed your thinking, widened your perspective in some way?
Absolutely.

I will bring back a special level of passion to our Internet rights, our free speech rights, our rights to assembly; because I could see so clearly how the control of this by the government could turn so easily into a tool of oppression.
Laura Murphy, thank you so much for talking to us.
Get back to the States safely.
Thank you, Michele.
That's Laura Murphy.
She's the director of the Washington Legislative Office of the ACLU.
She spoke to us from London.

If you're looking for final proof that machines are taking over even the most human of tasks, our producer Brent Baughman says he's found it in a new challenge being taken on by artificial intelligence.
Artificial intelligence already exists in a lot of places.
It's what recommends movies for your Netflix queue, and even some cars now have automatic parallel parking.
But the basic definition of artificial intelligence is when a machine learns to do something.
Basically something that a machine cannot do well, but a human can.
That's Dmitriy Genzel.
He's a researcher at Google.
And maybe you've used Google Translate to transform, say, English into Chinese.
Well, Dmitriy Genzel is part of a team at Google working with that same technology to tackle what he says is one of the biggest challenges in artificial intelligence: translating poetry.
And it's what computer scientists call AI complete.
AI complete.
Marilyn, thanks very much for the call.
We appreciate your time.
How embarrassing is it to the SEC that they could not catch a, people say, a $50 billion Ponzi scheme, despite multiple investigations and voluminous filings by Bernard Madoff?
It's probably the worst defeat for the agency in its history, certainly in recent memory.
It came after several difficult years when the SEC tried to take steps to monitor investment banks.
But the failure of those banks contributed to the financial crisis.
There are questions about whether the SEC was being tough on enforcement.
The new SEC chairman, Mary Schapiro, has promised to revive the agency.
She's promised to toughen up enforcement.
She's promised to introduce new policies, and in fact, has pursued new policies to make it more difficult for an operator like Madoff to run a Ponzi scheme.
Zachary Goldfarb, thank you very much for talking with us.
Thanks very much for having me.
And Mr. Goldfarb is a business and economics reporter for the Washington Post.
Among the thousands of people using the Internet to find missing relatives is Gabrielle Charles(ph).
She's a law student at Louisiana State University in Baton Rouge.
On Monday night her parents called from the rooftop of her family home in New Orleans just as their cell phone was losing power.
And my daddy was like, `OK, Gabby(ph), you need to call search and rescue now.
Just tell them that we're out here because the water's rising.
I'm like, `Oh, my God.'
Gabrielle and her sister began frantically calling local rescue operations.
Hours went by before Gabrielle got another phone call from her mother.
A helicopter had noticed the family waving a shirt from their rooftop.
Her mother and brother were pulled onto the helicopter, but there wasn't room for her father.
He would have to wait for the next one.
Then she got another call from her mother.
They weren't at like the Superdome and they weren't at like a major shelter.
I said, `Mama, can you charge your phone?
And she was like, `This place barely has power.
So I don't even know if it was really like a place.
Gabrielle has not heard from them since.
She is now glued to the television as she waits by the phone.
Basically I'm like a prisoner in my house.
I don't want to leave because I don't want to miss my mama calling me and I don't want to miss, you know, hearing my daddy's voice.
And I said, you know--as the week kept going by I'm like, `OK, so I haven't heard from my mom and I'm trying to hold it down, trying to be the strong one, the responsible one.
But, you know, I talk to my mom all day long constantly.
You know, how am I going to get through not talking to her, you know?
Gabrielle Charles has posted messages on a local television station's Web site.
She hopes someone will respond with news of her mother, Gwendolyn(ph), her father, Carlton(ph), and her brother, Emmitt Charles(ph), of New Orleans.
Today, we continue our look at the Mississippi Gulf Coast and how Hurricane Katrina is reshaping the economy there.
Insurance costs and land values have soared since the storm, prompting a shortage of affordable housing and pushing smaller businesses off the beach.
We're going to spend some time in the town of Pass Christian, nestled on a scenic peninsula surrounded by water.
My guide is longtime state representative Diane Peranich.
See, isn't it gorgeous?
Yes.
State Rep.
PERANICH: You can see the Mississippi sound off in the - those stripes, and somebody saw trace here where Christopher Columbus landed.
We're under a canopy of oaks in War Memorial Park at the center of town.
Virtually all of Pass Christian was wiped out by Hurricane Katrina, but the park is back.
There's a playground for children, picnic tables, a gazebo.
State Rep.
PERANICH: But the main thing is that debris is gone.
Think how wonderful that is.
You know, you can take a deep breath now and smell magnolias or jasmine or salt air.
A stretch of trailers lines the grounds.
State Rep.
PERANICH: So this has become the cultural center of the city and the home to our businesses.
The trailers house a sandwich shop and insurance office and a local bank, complete with a portable ATM out front.

It's just across the street from the city's municipal complex, where city hall, the police station, and other offices are also in temporary headquarters, a conglomeration of trailers and tents set up on what used to be the city tennis courts.
Representative Peranich takes me inside a doublewide on the edge of the park.
This is the library, which I learned has been the community hub since one month after the storm.
State Rep.
PERANICH: It was the heart of the community.
It held us together.
She introduces me to two women, waiting at a table amid the bookshelves.
My name is Sally James.
I will be 69 years old this June, and hopefully be in my house by that time.
I'm a lifelong resident of Pass Christian and I've been with the library system 24 years.
I'm Alice Russell.
I'm representing the Pass Christian Chamber of Commerce.
I am a former business owner.
Forced to retirement.
We owned one of the service stations right up on Scenic Drive that went for a swim that - we like to say a lot of our stuff went for a swim.
Alice Russell Stanley has been in Pass Christian for 100 years.
Her father was longtime city alderman.
She lost her brother-in-law to Katrina.

The Russell's have owned several businesses: a nursery, a bakeshop and since 1978, the Russell Service Center, a full service gas station and auto repair garage in what used to be the city's main business district on a bluff overlooking the beach.
But the family is in a dispute with its insurance company and has decided not to rebuild.
OK.
I think he'd have a better chance of getting famous if he decided on one or the other.
Ultimately ages tend to be known as--by a defining characteristic.

So if this was a boom--and, indeed, several years ago, if my memory serves me right, somebody wrote an essay describing this period as the long boom, and the feeling was that capitalism would ultimately lead to democracy and everything would turn out right.
This was a kind of post-Cold War optimism consistency with a Fukuyamist the end of history.
Or one could talk about this the age of bust.
I can spin together a scenario where this would be an era of financial ruin but also physical, a loss of safety because of disease, because of nuclear materials, global warming.
You can add together a set of developments, which this really could become something of a modern Dark Ages.
And obviously from a policy point of view, that's exactly the scenario we want to avoid.
We are trying to `name that era.
You can send us an e-mail at totn@npr.org if you want to do that.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Frank Stasio with Richard Haass, president of the Council on Foreign Relations.
And we're taking your calls, suggestions for what to name this era.
Bob is in Tulsa.
Hi, Bob.
Hi.
I suggest Lincoln III.
The age of Lincoln III?
Yes.
